**Chapter I**

On a very hot evening in July, a young man came out of the small room where he lived and walked slowly toward K. bridge, as if he was unsure about what to do.

He had managed to avoid seeing his landlady on the stairs. His room was at the top of a tall, five-story building and was more like a cupboard than a real room. The landlady, who provided him with the room, meals, and help, lived on the floor below him. Every time he left his room, he had to walk past her kitchen, which was always open. Each time he passed by, he felt sick and scared, which made him frown and feel embarrassed. He owed his landlady a lot of money and was afraid to run into her.

This wasnâ€™t because he was weak or timid; in fact, it was the opposite. For a while now, he had been very tense and irritable, almost to the point of being overly worried about his health. He had become so focused on himself and so isolated from other people that he feared meeting not just his landlady, but anyone at all. He was weighed down by poverty, but lately, he had stopped worrying about it. He had lost all interest in dealing with important matters. Nothing his landlady could do really scared him anymore. But to be...

**PAGE SUMMARY:** A young man, burdened by debt and isolation, hesitates to leave his cramped garret due to his fear of encountering his landlady.
